Paul May

Abacus

30 January 2011

A little bit of digging into one following the publication of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission (FCIC).

On the 27th of January the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission published its report; the product of 19 days of hearings, interviews with over 700 witnesses and a review of many millions of pages of documentation relating to the financial crisis. I haven’t had a chance to read the report, even open it, but the report’s website is a treasure-trove of documentation.

One document that caught my eye is “Goldman Sachs Abacas Trades” from November 2003. The document contains details of sales of subprime-mortgage backed collateralized debt obligations (CDOs) under a scheme called Abacus. Two Irish banks feature in the document, Anglo Irish Bank and Allied Irish Bank. AIB is shown to have bought $80m of Abacus and Anglo Irish bought $11m.

Abacus became incredibly controversial; partly because the mortgages it wrapped up and sold as investments were very risky (toxic), but also because later (in 2006) it is alleged that one of Goldman’s major clients - a hedge fund called Magnetar - encouraged Goldman to include higher and higher risk mortgages in CDOs like Abacus, sponsored their creation (buying the highest risk components of the deals, making them viable), then bet against their performance. Magnetar denies any part in the creation of these high-risk deals.

One case, involving Goldman Sachs employee Fabrice Tourre who created and sold the CDO called “Abacus 2007-AC1” is notorious; Tourre bragged that he would be the only one left standing when deals like Abacus came crashing down - but it appears as though his deal was one in a long line of very risky stuff packaged and sold on to investors by Goldman Sachs.

So, in short - Abacus CDOs were risky, and in some cases may have been set up to fail so that companies going short on Abacus CDOs like Magnetar would make a profit.

In subsequent years Abacus CDOs did indeed fail, spectacularly to the point where thy became “impaired” beyond the point of no return. I am not sure what happened to AIB and Anglo’s liability; perhaps the whole value of their investment in Abacus CDOs was written off - who knows.

From this one document you see that Irish banks were in the mix with a lot of very large global banks, hedge funds - investing in risky stuff, playing with the big children. There are millions of other documents like this - It’s fascinating, scary stuff.

Bet Against the American Dream

This is about the most concise version of what I’m writing about here; made by the astounding team at Planet Money.
